speaker: JAY GILMORE
line: Anson? Anson, where are you, Anson? Anson, come back, Anson. Anson. Calling Anson. Where are you, Anson? Anson! Anson, calling Anson. Where are you, Anson? Anson! Where are you, Anson?

speaker: JAY GILMORE
line: Anson! Get out here.

speaker: JAY GILMORE
line: I warned you about your attitude. Did you clean out 407? No... of course you haven't cleaned out 407. You've only had all damn morning. You think you're ever going to own any of those boats in that magazine the way you're going, huh? Do you think you're ever going to amount to anything? You can't even finish a simple job.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: A monkey could do this job, right, Jay?

speaker: JAY GILMORE
line: Well, you can't, so what's that say about you?

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: Oh, shut up.

speaker: JAY GILMORE
line: Excuse me? I didn't catch that. You clean out 407. You move out that deadbeat's stuff, and you do it now. And when I come back in an hour, it better be done.

speaker: JAY GILMORE
line: Anson... Anson? Son of a... Anson. Anson!

speaker: JAY GILMORE
line: Aw, that's it, Anson. Do you hear me, Anson?

speaker: MULDER
line: Can I get you some coffee? Water? Anything?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Morning.

speaker: MULDER
line: Morning.

speaker: MULDER
line: Special Agent Dana Scully, this is, uh, this is Jay Gilmore.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Nice to meet you.

speaker: JAY GILMORE
line: Nice to meet...

speaker: JAY GILMORE
line: Likewise.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mr. Gilmore came all the way to see us from Missouri, the "Show Me" state.

speaker: JAY GILMORE
line: They told me you were the people to best understand my situ... My sit...

speaker: MULDER
line: It's okay. Uh, this is Mr. Gilmore's... situation. This condition came on very suddenly about a month ago.

speaker: JAY GILMORE
line: Anson Stokes-- he did this to me. I don't know how, I just... I know it was him.

speaker: MULDER
line: Anson Stokes is a former employee at the, uh, self-storage yard that Mr. Gilmore owns. Uh, apparently, there was some bad blood between you two.

speaker: JAY GILMORE
line: He told me to shut up! Huh?!

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. And then Mr. Gilmore was, uh... stricken...

speaker: MULDER
line: Stricken... stricken, and Anson Stokes was nowhere to be found. He resurfaced several days later and the police wanted to question him. But he refused.

speaker: JAY GILMORE
line: Do you know what he said? He said they had nothing on him.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, and to be fair, sir, they didn't-- they don't.

speaker: JAY GILMORE
line: They had to make me a whole new mouth. Do you think Blue Cross is going to pay for this? Uh-uh.

speaker: JAY GILMORE
line: I demand justice!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Look, Mulder, all I'm saying is...

speaker: MULDER
line: I know-- this may not be a crime and this guy Stokes may not know anything about it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But there is a condition called microstomia-- "small mouth"-- which is, uh, it's brought on by the disease scleroderma and it's the overproduction of collagen and it can actually reduce a person's mouth to a tiny little opening.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, but that takes months to develop, right? It doesn't just happen in the blink of an eye. Gilmore's surgeons are stumped. They're writing it up in the New England Journal of Medicine.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, there's always nasal aplasia-- the complete absence of a nose.

speaker: MULDER
line: That's a nose, Scully; we're talking mouth here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah, but what we're talking, Mulder, is medical-- physiological-- not criminal. Not as far as I can see.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, maybe, but I still want to know why Anson Stokes doesn't want to talk to the police.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder...

speaker: SCULLY
line: That's a little... out of place, wouldn't you say?

speaker: MULDER
line: A little bit.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: Aw, damn it. Leslie!

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: What? What is it?

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: They're I.R.S. agents. They got to be. Listen, get rid of them, all right?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Hi. We're looking for a Mr. Anson Stokes.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: He's not here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, do you happen to know when he's coming back?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, we are, uh, Agents Mulder and Scully from the FBI.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Oh, the boat's... the boat's not ours. The boat … I'm... we're just holding it for someone, and, you know-- they pay the taxes on it.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Okay...

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Anson's not here.

speaker: MULDER
line: Whoa, whoa, whoa, whoa. What's your name?

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Leslie Stokes.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, you're Anson's brother?

speaker: MULDER
line: Hi, there.

speaker: MULDER
line: We're not here to talk about the boat, Leslie. We want to talk to your brother about his former employer. Mr. Gilmore?

speaker: SCULLY
line: And the, uh... unfortunate condition that he's found himself in. Would you happen to know anything about that?

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: What, the mouth thing? Yeah, well, that-- you know, that's-that's just, uh, that's, like... chemicals.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Chemicals?

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Yeah, you know, like, people store weird chemicals, well like... my brother one time, he smelled this weird smell? You know, he's just a guy with a meth lab, like in one of the storage units, so you know, that's actually probably something you guys should look into-- take a look into that... you know, I'm going to get going, so I'm going to go, okay?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Okay.

speaker: MULDER
line: Now I see what's going on here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, according to Gilmore he was standing right where I am when it happened.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, I don't smell any weird chemical smells. You still have both your lips.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Apparently, everything is left as it was.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey... 1978. It's been a long time since any of this stuff has seen the light of day.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, it's too bad, Mulder. Underneath all this dust, this furniture is really wonderful.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, well, you want to hit some yard sales while we're out here?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, this furniture is expensive, very expensive.

speaker: MULDER
line: What's your point?

speaker: SCULLY
line: My point is that, uh... there's a lot of money sitting around here and maybe something's missing.

speaker: MULDER
line: Like what?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't know-- jewelry. I mean, Anson Stokes opened up this storage unit and then he just disappeared.

speaker: MULDER
line: And winds up with the Titanic in his driveway?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mm-hmm. There's your crime: Theft.

speaker: MULDER
line: That still doesn't explain what happened to Gilmore.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well...

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, Scully, check this out.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Ouch.

speaker: MULDER
line: This woman look familiar to you?

speaker: SCULLY
line: That's the woman from the trailer.

speaker: MULDER
line: That's the –young- woman from the trailer. How many centuries now has disco been dead?

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: Two down. Two down, I got nothing to show for it.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: You got the boat.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: And what the hell good is that? Huh? That thing is like a big... you know, big...

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: White elephant?

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: What? I'm sorry. What does that mean?

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: It's a big expensive item that serves no purpose and is ultimately more trouble than it's worth.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: So what the hell did you give it to me for?

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: Because you asked for it.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: Fine. You know what? I can appreciate that. That's... but don't you think maybe you could've found some frickin' water to put it in?

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: You didn't specify water.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: I got to specify that you put a boat in the frickin' water? That is a given. Frickin' white elephant. I can't even pay the taxes on it.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Why don't you just, uh, use your last wish to get rid of it?

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: You want me to put you in a home or something, maybe, right now? Because I just told you, Leslie, that I wasted two wishes, okay? And I am not... are you listening? I am not going to waste the third. All right? Come on. Come on. We got to concentrate here. Now, let me figure this out. Let me figure this out. Third wish, third wish, third wish, final wish. Hey, I'm just spit-balling here, all right? If I happen to say, "I wish," by accident, that does not count, not until I am absolutely ready, okay?

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: You could always give that guy his mouth back.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: Hey, all I said was that I wish Jay would shut the hell up. If you feel bad about what you did to him fix it on your own dime, okay?

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: It doesn't work like that.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: Whatever. Leslie, would you help me out here?

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Uh... Money. Wish for money.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: Yeah, okay, that's not bad. That's not bad, that's not bad, but don't you think maybe we should think of something that would, generate money instead of the, actually the money itself?

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: Brains? Talent? Hard work?

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Uh... A money machine. Huh?

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: That's not... but something better. Something better. Okay, but...

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: An infinite number of wishes?

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: Okay.

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: Just three boys. Settle down.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: Damn it, this is hard.

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: You know, I have a thought. Granted, it's pretty obvious.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: What? What, what, what?

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: What?

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: What?

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: Seriously, what?

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: Oh, forget it.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: I got it.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Yeah?

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: I got it. I got it, I got it, I got it. Okay. Okay. Are you ready? Because I am ready. I am absolutely ready. Okay, here goes. I wish that I could turn invisible … at will.

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: You're kidding.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: No, no. This is perfect. Yeah, I could have an advantage that nobody else on earth can have. I can, um, you know, spy and learn secret information, pick up stock tips.

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: Sneak into a women's locker room.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: Not just that, okay? I'm talking about James Bond type stuff. You know?

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: Your wish is breathtaking in its un-originality.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: You don't have to like it, all right? You just have to do it. Right?

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: Done.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: My clothes are going to turn invisible, too, right?

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: You didn't specify clothes.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: I know, but... screw it.

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: Oh, God. Turn invisible please.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: Yes! Oh, man, this is awesome! Hey. Hey, brother. Hey, Leslie? I'm over here. Oop, I'm over here. Can you see me?

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: Oof. Ow! Damn it.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Anson, you all right?

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: Yeah, I am. I can't see my damn feet. Look out, world! Here I come! Whoo-hoo!

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: I'm invisible! Invisible, baby! Whoo!

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Whoo-oo!

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: Yes! You can't see me, can you!

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Hey, uh...?

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: Hey, out of my way, birds.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: Hello, ladies.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: Yeah, here comes Anson. That's right. Come on, come on, come on. Change, change.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: All right, here we go. Need a little roadside assistance, do ya? Well, not to worry. Here comes Anson.

speaker: KID
line: Whooooaaa!!!

speaker: MORGUE ATTENDANT
line: Can we go now?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mm-hmm.

speaker: MULDER
line: I think you missed a spot here. I can see straight through to his ass.

speaker: MULDER
line: This is Anson Stokes, huh?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It is. His dental records are a match. He was found about half a mile from his house. He was probably hit by a car or a truck or... something.

speaker: MULDER
line: And he's invisible.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yes, he is.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You know, Mulder, in the seven years that we've been working together I have seen some amazing things, but this? This takes the cake. It's... it's going to change the boundaries of science.

speaker: MULDER
line: It is amazing, but I don't think it has anything to do with science. Remember Mr. Saturday Night Fever?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: I did a little background checking. His real name is Henry Flanken. He redefined the term "overnight success." In 1977, his net worth was $36,000, and in 1978 it was $30 million. Then there is the interesting way in which Mr. Flanken died.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How's that?

speaker: MULDER
line: Chronic morbid tumescence.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You don't mean what I think you mean?

speaker: MULDER
line: Sch-wing. On April 4, 1978, he was admitted to Gateway Memorial Hospital with an extreme priapic condition. Apparently, he was quite the specimen. They had to raise the doorframe in order to wheel him into his hospital room.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, what does any of that have to do with this?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, I think our mystery woman is the link. About whom I can find no information whatsoever. I think she's responsible for all of this.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But how?

speaker: MULDER
line: I... I don't know. But... we need to talk to her.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Uh, I think that I should stay here with the body. I mean, I... you know, I don't think it's a good idea to leave him unguarded. You know, this is truly amazing.

speaker: MULDER
line: Okay.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm very sorry for your loss.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Anson didn't suffer, did he?

speaker: MULDER
line: No, I don't think he suffered. The part about him being invisible-- that doesn't, uh, catch you off guard just a little bit?

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Uh...

speaker: MULDER
line: Leslie, there was a woman here earlier. Where is she now?

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: She's, uh... she's gone.

speaker: MULDER
line: Uh, let me tell you where I'm going with this. I think that woman is a jinniyah. Are you familiar with that term?

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: No.

speaker: MULDER
line: It's the feminine for jinni-- as in a demon or spirit from Middle Eastern folklore.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, except Barbara Eden never killed anybody. All right, now in Arabic mythology they speak of these beings that are composed of flame or air but take human form. They can perform certain tasks or grant certain wishes. They live in inanimate objects like a lamp or a ring. Is this beginning to sound familiar?

speaker: MULDER
line: Leslie, I believe your brother found just such an object in the storage facility, didn't he? He took possession of the jinniyah and he made some pretty outrageous requests, like Jay Gilmore's mouth and the yacht in the driveway.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Oh, wait, wait. You believe all that?

speaker: MULDER
line: I do. And, Leslie, for your own safety-- so that what happened to your brother doesn't happen to you-- I think you should hand over that object to me right now.

speaker: MULDER
line: You're doing the right thing.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, Scully, come check this out.

speaker: MULDER
line: Come on, he's not going anywhere. Come on.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Bye.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I have a group of researchers flying in from Harvard Medical. Can't wait to see their faces.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What's this?

speaker: MULDER
line: It's not what I hoped it would be. Judging from the odor coming inside, I think it's where the Stokes brothers keep their weed.

speaker: MULDER
line: But that's not what I wanted to show you. Recognize him?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Benito Mussolini.

speaker: MULDER
line: How about her?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Your mystery woman. Or someone who looks a lot like her.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, the computer says it is her. I ran her through Quantico's facial recognition software and couldn't come up with a match in the known felon database. Then I took a flier and checked with the image bank at the national archives. Voila.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, even if it is her, Mulder, what would she be doing with Mussolini?

speaker: MULDER
line: Or Richard Nixon, for that matter.

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't know. Except that they're both men who got all the power they ever wished for and then lost it.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: See? I told you it'd look good in here. Nice rug. How do you breathe in that thing, huh?

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: Can we just get this over with, please? Three wishes. Go.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Okay. Don't rush me, all right? I want to do this right. Got to be smarter than Anson was.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Damn it, Anson.

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: Then, can I once again offer you a suggestion?

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Hmm?

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: What?

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: This. Your disability? There was some tragedy involved here, I assume.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Yeah, well, yeah, it was pretty tragic, I guess. Me and Anson were playing mailbox baseball. God, I miss that. And Anson's driving. I was leaning pretty far out the window there. Oh. You mean this?

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: Mm-hmm.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Yeah, you're right. I could wish for a solid gold wheelchair. Man, that'd be sweet.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: I see what you're saying but you know what? There's something I want more than that.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You're not going to believe your eyes. I certainly didn't. You ready?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Uh, he's, uh... he's invisible... after all... Um...

speaker: SCULLY
line: He's in there.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Okay. You know what? He's creeping me out. This isn't what I asked for. He's all weird and messed up.

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: He's been hit by a truck. What did you expect?

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: I asked you to bring him back to normal.

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: You asked me to bring him back.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Okay, you know, the...

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Now, he's starting to smell bad! Come on-- this isn't what I wanted! Look, he's got to at least be able to talk. Okay... You know what? That's my next wish.

speaker: WISH NUMBER TWO
line: I wish Anson could talk.

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: No, you don't.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Yes, I do and that's final. I wish Anson could talk.

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: Done.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh, I should just shoot myself. Oh... I was so happy. I was so excited. What was I thinking? An invisible man?

speaker: MULDER
line: You saw it. It was real.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I don't know what I saw, Mulder. I do know that having that kind of proof in my hands it was just too good to be true.

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't think that's why the body disappeared.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why did the body disappear?

speaker: MULDER
line: I think it was the result of a wish being granted.

speaker: SCULLY
line: A wish? Whose wish?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, who would want Anson Stokes back? I mean, really, really back.

speaker: SCULLY
line: His brother, Leslie.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Well, this is no good.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: What did you do to me?

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: What? You're back from the dead, man. What kind of gratitude is that?

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: What did you do to me?

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: I wasted two wishes on you. That's what I did.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: I can't feel my heart.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: I-I can't feel my blood. I am yellow! I'm cold.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Screw this!

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: I'm cold. I'm cold.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: I wasted two wishes on you. And a perfectly good bowl of corn flakes.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: There, I turned the heat up. Are you happy now? Huh? Are you happy? Is there anything else I can do for you there, buddy?

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: What do you say? Maybe wipe your little yellow butt? Thanks for nothing.

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: You want to make your third wish, champ? I'd like to get out of here before the blowflies hatch.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Yeah, I tell you what-- my last wish is going to be for me, okay? It's going to be for me, you hear that, Anson? I wasted two wishes on you and you don't even give a damn about that! All right... third wish. Uh... let's see, I could wish for, uh... I could wish for money. Not everybody wishes for money.

speaker: ANSON STOKES
line: It's so cold.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: No, um... or there's the invisibility thing. I guess that turned out pretty stupid huh? Anson? To be invisible! That was real smart, huh?

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Uh... X-ray eyes, maybe? No, that would be... hmm, like you said, solid gold wheelchair.

speaker: LESLIE STOKES
line: Uh... wait, I got it-- legs!

speaker: MULDER
line: Would you mind removing your eyewear, ma'am?

speaker: MULDER
line: Ah. Do you have a name?

speaker: DARK-HAIRED WOMAN
line: Not for a long time now.

speaker: MULDER
line: How about if I call you Jenn? That's short for "jinniyah."

speaker: SCULLY
line: The, uh... the fire department just recovered two bodies.

speaker: MULDER
line: Leslie Stokes and his brother, Anson.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Looks like it. And, uh, Anson Stokes is visible now. Of course.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But what I'd really love an explanation for is how his corpse got from my locked morgue all the way across town to the Mark Twain Trailer Park.

speaker: JENN
line: Ask him. He's got it all figured out.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I know what he'd say. He'd say that you're some kind of a jinni from 1,001 Nights or something like that and that you grant people wishes.

speaker: JENN
line: Well, there you have it.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, one thing I haven't been able to figure out is whether you're a good jinni or an evil one. Everybody you come in contact with seems to meet a bad end.

speaker: JENN
line: That's the conclusion you've drawn? That I'm evil?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, possibly evil. Possibly cursed. A curse to others.

speaker: JENN
line: The only thing you people are cursed with is stupidity. All of you. Everybody. Mankind. Everyone I have ever come into contact with without fail. Always asking for the wrong thing.

speaker: MULDER
line: You mean making the wrong wishes.

speaker: JENN
line: Yeah, it's always: "Give me money. Give me big boobs. " "Give me a big hoo-hoo. Make me cool like the Fonz." Or whoever's the big name now.

speaker: MULDER
line: You been out of circulation a long time.

speaker: JENN
line: So what? In 500 years, people have not changed a bit.

speaker: SCULLY
line: 500 years.

speaker: JENN
line: Granted, they smell better now generally speaking but human greed still reigns... shallowness... a propensity for self-destruction.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You're saying that you have been a firsthand witness to 500 years of human history.

speaker: JENN
line: I used to be human. I was born in 15th century France and then, one day, an old Moor came to my village peddling rugs and I unrolled one that an Ifrit had taken residence in.

speaker: SCULLY
line: "An Ifrit."

speaker: JENN
line: A very... powerful class of jinni. He offered me three wishes. For the first I asked for a stouthearted mule. For the second, a magic sack that was always full of turnips...

speaker: JENN
line: Did I mention this was 15th century France?

speaker: MULDER
line: What was your third wish?

speaker: JENN
line: My third... I pondered for a great while. I didn't want to waste it. So, finally, feeling very intelligent I spoke up and I said "Je souhaite un grand pouvoir et une longue vie." "I wish for great power and long life."

speaker: MULDER
line: And thus became a jinni yourself.

speaker: JENN
line: Gave me the mark of the jinn... … right there. It's forever. Sort of like a prison tattoo.

speaker: JENN
line: I should've been more specific. So, am I under arrest?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I can't think of anything we have to hold you on. And, not surprisingly we don't have any evidence of any of this, so, uh... I think she's free to go.

speaker: JENN
line: No, I'm not. He unrolled me.

speaker: MULDER
line: I get three wishes.

speaker: JENN
line: So your partner left the airport rather quickly. And I don't think she likes me very much.

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't think she knows what to make of you. I don't think I do either, really.

speaker: JENN
line: Well, you could always give up your three wishes. I'll disappear-- no hard feelings.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mmmm.

speaker: JENN
line: I didn't think so. So, what's your first wish?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well...

speaker: MULDER
line: What would your wish be if you were in my place?

speaker: JENN
line: I'm not you. It doesn't matter.

speaker: MULDER
line: But, I just... you know, I'd like to know.

speaker: JENN
line: I'd... wish that I'd never heard the word "wish" before. I'd wish that I could live my life moment by moment... enjoying it for what it is instead of... instead of worrying about what it isn't.

speaker: JENN
line: I'd... sit down somewhere with a great cup of coffee and I'd watch the world go by. But then again, I'm not you. So I doubt that's your wish.

speaker: MULDER
line: You know, I think I'm beginning to see the problem here. You say that most people make the wrong wishes, right?

speaker: JENN
line: Without fail. It's like giving a chimpanzee a revolver.

speaker: MULDER
line: This is because they make their wishes solely for personal gain.

speaker: JENN
line: Could be.

speaker: MULDER
line: So the trick would be to make a wish that's totally altruistic. That's for everyone. So, um... I wish for peace on earth.

speaker: JENN
line: Peace on earth. That's it?

speaker: MULDER
line: What the hell's wrong with that? You can't do it?

speaker: JENN
line: No. I can.

speaker: JENN
line: It's done.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh, crap.

speaker: MULDER
line: I guess I should have seen this coming! Scully.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully?

speaker: MULDER
line: Hello? Hello?

speaker: MULDER
line: Very good. Jinni? Jinni, whatever the hell your name is...

speaker: JENN
line: Yes?

speaker: MULDER
line: What the hell is this?

speaker: JENN
line: It's what you asked for. Peace on earth. Listen.

speaker: MULDER
line: You know damn well that's not what I meant.

speaker: JENN
line: You didn't specify.

speaker: MULDER
line: This has nothing to do with specificity. You don't have to wipe out the entire population of the whole planet just to effect a little peace on earth and goodwill towards men.

speaker: JENN
line: You didn't say goodwill towards men. So you expect me to change the hearts of six billion people? No religion in history has been able to pull that off. Not Allah or Buddha or Christ. But you'd like me to do that in your name? So... what? You can feel real good about yourself?

speaker: MULDER
line: Did I say that? I didn't say that.

speaker: JENN
line: Mm, how grotesquely egotistical of you. I bet you wish you hadn't made your first wish.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yes, I do, since you butchered the intent of that wish so completely. And another thing-- I think you've got a really horrible attitude. I guess that comes from being rolled up in a rug for the last 500 years.

speaker: MULDER
line: But we're not all that stupid. We're not all chimpanzees with revolvers. I think there's another possibility here and that's just that you're a bitch.

speaker: SKINNER
line: Agent Mulder?

speaker: MULDER
line: Sir.

speaker: SKINNER
line: How did you get in here?

speaker: MULDER
line: Uh...

speaker: (THE WISH
line: "Whereas, I have one wish left and desire to use it most effectively for the good of all mankind, and whereas this wish contains great potential for the betterment of life as we know it, and that equal potential for grave danger, chaos, and mayhem, let effect, a world run amok, and whereas, I must cover all bases…"

speaker: JENN
line: "Whereas, I have one wish left and desire to use it most effectively for the good of all mankind" yadda, yadda, yadda... "Here on this plane of existence..." Hmm... Hmm-hmm. What, are you a lawyer?

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, I have to be with you. I'm going to get this last wish perfect. I'm not going to leave you any loopholes. I'm not going to let you interpret this as an edict to bring back the Third Reich or to make everyone's eyes grow on stalks.

speaker: JENN
line: Oh, geez. And I was so looking forward to that.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Skinner called me, Mulder. Is everything all right?

speaker: MULDER
line: You don't remember disappearing off the face of the earth for about an hour this morning?

speaker: SCULLY
line: No.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, I guess everything's okay.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mul...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Could you give us a minute, please?

speaker: JENN
line: Sure.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Like today?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Wh … Where the hell did she go?

speaker: MULDER
line: Boink!

speaker: SCULLY
line: No... It's got to be hypnotism or mesmerism or … something.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully, it is what it is. You examined an invisible body, remember?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I thought I did.

speaker: MULDER
line: Oh!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, all right, say... say that you're right. Say this is what it is. Then what you're doing is extraordinarily dangerous. I mean, you even said that yourself.

speaker: MULDER
line: The trick is to be specific. To make the wish perfect. That way, everyone is going to benefit. It's going to be a safer world, a happier world. There's going to be food for everyone, freedom for everyone, the end of the tyranny of the powerful over the weak. Am I leaving anything out?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It sounds wonderful.

speaker: MULDER
line: Then what's the problem?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Maybe it's the whole point of our lives here, Mulder-- to achieve that. Maybe it's a process that one man shouldn't try and circumvent with a single wish.

speaker: JENN
line: You ready?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, I'm ready.

speaker: MULDER
line: I can't believe you don't want butter on your popcorn. Uggh. It's un- American.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Caddyshack," Mulder?

speaker: MULDER
line: It's a classic American movie.

speaker: SCULLY
line: That's what every guy says. It's a guy movie.

speaker: MULDER
line: Okay, when you invite me over to your place we can watch Steel Magnolias.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So, uh... What's the occasion?

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't know. Just felt like the thing to do. Cheers.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Cheers.

speaker: MULDER
line: I don't know if you noticed but, um, I never made the world a happier place.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, I'm fairly happy. That's something.

speaker: ANNOUNCER MAN ON VIDEO TAPE WITH NO PREVIEWS
line: And now, our feature presentation.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So what was your final wish, anyway?

speaker: KENNY LOGGINS SINGING CADDYSHACK THEME
line: Dup-dup-dup-dup-dup-dup-dup-dup-dup I'm all right...

speaker: WAITRESS
line: Here you go.
